title: There's something weird about my parents' suit of armor
body:
A few days ago, Mom came home with a suit of armor.

My parents are constantly buying garish, over-the-top home décor. They think, for some reason, it’ll make our 2000 square-foot colonial look like a mansion. We’ve got a gold-trimmed mirror in the foyer, Oriental rugs in the family room, silver-plated tea sets in the kitchen…

And now a suit of armor in the living room.

Now, because this is Nosleep, you're probably expecting some terrifying description. Like – it’s an authentic, 18th-century suit of armor that a knight was murdered in. Well… it’s not. It’s a 7-foot-tall piece of crap, cobbled together from scrap metal and sheets of tin. My mom paid like fifty bucks for it at some garden store. Here's a photo if it, if you're curious.

Anyway, on Tuesday night, it was raining buckets. I woke up around 2am from the sharp crack of thunder, and then I couldn’t fall back asleep. I decided to go downstairs to get a glass of water.

As I reached the last stair, I jumped.

There was the suit of armor. Standing there, in the foyer, in front of the gold mirror.

I shook my head. Dad must’ve moved it last night, after I went to sleep. “You’re going to give me a heart attack,” I muttered, staring at the chink in the metal where his eyes would have been.

I went into the kitchen and got the glass of water. Mr. Whiskers stirred listlessly in his bed. I then started back towards the stairs – but not before smiling at the suit of armor.

“Night owl, huh?” I whispered to him.

Silence, of course, unless you count the rain pattering against the glass.

“Hey, between you and me, you’re kind of handsome,” I said. “I like tall guys. Especially tall, shiny guys.”

I chuckled.

And then I noticed it.

He looked… more shiny than usual. In the overhead lights, the metal of his visor was gleaming brightly.

I walked over, and leaned in.

He was wet.

“Huh, that’s weird,” I said, swiping a finger across his helmet. Sure enough, it came away wet. I looked up at the ceiling – but I didn’t see a leak of any kind.

A few minutes later, I went to bed.

The next morning, I forgot all about my rendez-vous with Sir Knight. I was late for school, and Mrs. Urman was already on the warpath against “senioritis.”

But as I screeched out of the driveway, I was intercepted by our neighbor, Mrs. Timms. I would’ve just ignored her, but she’s super nice. She even gave me 50 bucks as an early graduation present.

“Emily!” she yelled. “Emily, can I talk to you?”

I reluctantly rolled down the window. “Mrs. Timms, I’m late for school –”

“You have a lot to answer for, young lady.”

Her brusque tone caught me off guard. “Uh, what?” I said, suddenly wondering if the red-faced woman was the same gentle-mannered neighbor I knew.

“One of my chickens is missing.”

“I’m really sorry to hear that, but –”

“It’s that damned cat of yours!” she bellowed.

“What?”

“Don’t deny it. Penny’s feathers are right there, in your front yard!”

I turned. Sure enough, a few buff-colored feathers scattered the grass.

“You make sure your damned cat stays inside, or you’ll be sorry,” she growled. Then she stalked back down the driveway, and slammed the front door shut.

I made my way to school, but I couldn’t get my mind off Mrs. Timms all day. While I had no doubts that Mr. Whiskers was innocent (he didn’t have a drop of blood on him), I felt just awful. She loved those chickens with all her heart.

So after school, I immediately ran over to her house. Clack, clack, clack. I swung the knocker hard. “Mrs. Timms!” I called, gripping the box of chocolates I had bought her. “Mrs. Timms?”

No answer.

But I knew she was in there, because I heard the distinctive clang of dishes and pots coming from deep within the house.

Annoyed, I shoved the chocolates into her mailbox and walked into my house.

My parents were at work. I dropped my backpack on the floor, and walked into the kitchen. Pulled out a yogurt, and opened the trash to throw out the top.

That’s when I saw it.

A chicken carcass, lying at the top of the garbage.

Picked clean.

Maybe it was Mr. Whiskers, I thought, heart pounding. My parents must’ve found the body, and thrown it away. But somehow it looked… too clean. There wasn’t a drop of blood, a fiber of meat left on the thing.

I shut the garbage and turned away.

There stood the suit of armor in the foyer, still as a statue.

A lone feather stuck to his sword.

It was about 3 AM when I heard the racket and pulled myself out of bed.

A metallic clanging noise, over the sheets of rain, as if someone was banging pots and pans together. Rubbing the sleep out of my eyes, I walked over to the window. What kind of idiot thinks it’s okay to make this much noise?!

I parted the blinds and peered out.

A glint of fire.

What the hell?

I swung out of my bedroom. Someone must have thrown a cigarette in the grass, and it caught fire, I thought. I thundered down the stairs.

As I reached the bottom, my breath caught in my throat.

The suit of armor was gone from the foyer.

I ran to the front door. I grabbed the doorknob, and was about to yank it open, when –

A rumbling, terrible roar shook the house.

Then the house flashed with gold, as a blast of fire pierced the darkness outside.
author: BlairDaniels
